OSGi

OSGi: Open Services Gateway initiative is a standard (Java framework) for modularity layer on the Java platform.

OSGi has two parts. The first is a specification for modular components called Bundles. The specification defines an infrastructure for a bundle’s life cycle and determines how bundles will interact. The second is a JVM-level service registry that bundles can use to publish, discover and bind to services in a Service-Oriented Architecture.

You can learn more about OSGi in here.

This post will be served as a quick guide to develop OSGi components, a producer component to publish services and a consumer component to use the published service to fulfill its requirements.

Implementation

Fabricator

Fabricator (Producer) component has a single service which is exposed to the outside to generate and provide facts about the OS and the logged-in user. The current implementation uses a model named Fact to share the data between OSGi components.

Given below is the implementation of the class named FactFabricator which exposes a single service named getSimpleFact().

The Fabricator component has to be registered with the Bundle Context in order to be used by other service components.

Shopper

Shopper (Consumer) component is used to retrieve the facts using the exposed services of Fabricator component. The current implementation is to retrieve the data and to print on console.

The Shopper component also has to be registered as a service component with Bundle Context. But, as of this sample, the activate() method is used to retrieve facts straightway without registering the service component.

In order to grab the exposed service, a Reference annotation has been used to annotate and to refer our Fabricator service component.
